item.title: Italian, French Bond Spreads Could Widen Amid Focus on Fiscal Metrics
item.description: Following higher-than-expected 2023 Italian and French budget deficits, focus on eurozone government bond fundamentals and fears of negative rating actions have put pressure on country spreads, Societe Generale Research said.

item.title: Japan Government Watching Currency Movements Closely
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said his government wouldn’t rule out any measures in dealing with foreign-exchange rates.

item.title: Apple Lays Off 614 Workers After Canceling Car Project
item.description: The tech giant announced its first major job cuts since the pandemic on the heels of its decision to cancel its vaunted electric-car project.

item.title: Shell Sees Gas Output Above Guidance
item.description: Shell said it expects gas production to beat its previous guidance after a strong first quarter..

item.title: Alaska Air Group received a $160 million payment from Boeing as initial compensation to make up for lost profits due to the midair blowout of a door plug on a flight in January.
item.description: Alaska Air Group received a $160 million payment from Boeing as initial compensation to make up for lost profits due to the midair blowout of a door plug on a flight in January.

item.title: An Airbus unit developing high-altitude drones could consider an initial public offering after it launches commercial operations in the coming years, its chief executive said.
item.description: An Airbus unit developing high-altitude drones could consider an initial public offering after it launches commercial operations in the coming years, its chief executive said.

item.title: A U.S. judge spared Joe Lewis from prison time for the British billionaire's role in an insider-trading scheme, citing his age and poor health.
item.description: A U.S. judge spared Joe Lewis from prison time for the British billionaire’s role in an insider-trading scheme, citing his age and poor health.

item.title: Telecom Italia Secures Finance Until Close of Network Sale
item.description: Telecom Italia has signed an agreement for roughly $1.6 billion in bridge financing to cover its needs until completion of a planned sale of its fixed-network unit.

item.title: German Factory Orders Post Disappointing Rise
item.description: German manufacturing orders rose 0.2% in February, lower than economists’ forecasts and reflecting only a moderate rebound as demand for goods remains sluggish.

item.title: Nikkei Falls 2.0%, Dragged by Brokerage, Chip Stocks
item.description: Japanese stocks ended lower, dragged by falls in brokerage and chip-related stocks, as hopes dim for an early Fed rate cut.

item.title: China Oilfield Services Suspends Operations of Four Mideast Rigs
item.description: China Oilfield Services has suspended operations of drilling rigs related to a multibillion-dollar contract in the Middle East, a setback for China’s largest offshore drilling contractor in one of its most important international markets.

item.title: India Central Bank Holds Rate Steady as Economy Stays Strong
item.description: India’s central bank kept its policy rate unchanged as the country’s economic growth remains strong and inflation eases.

item.title: Why Immigration Is Now the No. 1 Issue for Voters
item.description: The topic—a weak spot for President Biden—ranks as more important than inflation and the economy, recent polls show.

item.title: Can Europe Still Count on America's Nuclear Umbrella?
item.description: With U.S. commitments in doubt as never before, leaders from Paris to Warsaw are facing the prospect of deterring Putin on their own.

item.title: Stanford University named its business school dean as its next president after the prior leader resigned amid questions about research misconduct.
item.description: Stanford University named its business school dean as its next president after the prior leader resigned amid questions about research misconduct.

item.title: U.S. stocks fell sharply after Fed officials cooled talk of interest-rate cuts this year. The S&P 500 dropped 1.2% while the Dow and Nasdaq both slid 1.4%.
item.description: U.S. stocks fell sharply after Fed officials cooled talk of interest-rate cuts this year. The S&P 500 dropped 1.2% while the Dow and Nasdaq both slid 1.4%.

item.title: The FDA is drafting a proposal to drop a broad ban on anonymous sperm donations by gay and bisexual men in favor of more pointed screening questions to assess HIV risk.
item.description: The FDA is drafting a proposal to drop a broad ban on anonymous sperm donations by gay and bisexual men in favor of more pointed screening questions to assess HIV risk.

item.title: No Labels, the centrist group that has sought to field a third-party presidential bid, abandoned efforts to create a "unity ticket" aiming to win the White House.
item.description: No Labels, the centrist group that has sought to field a third-party presidential bid, abandoned efforts to create a “unity ticket” aiming to win the White House.

item.title: Israel's military scrambled GPS signals as the country braced for possible retaliation by Iran or one of its allied militias for a suspected Israeli airstrike on an Iranian diplomatic building in Syria.
item.description: Israel’s military scrambled GPS signals as the country braced for possible retaliation by Iran or one of its allied militias for a suspected Israeli airstrike on an Iranian diplomatic building in Syria.

item.title: Biden warned Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu that future U.S. support hinges on protecting civilians and aid workers in Gaza, signaling for the first time that the White House would reassess backing Israel's war in the enclave.
item.description: Biden warned Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu that future U.S. support hinges on protecting civilians and aid workers in Gaza, signaling for the first time that the White House would reassess backing Israel’s war in the enclave.
